Measurements:Head and body: 910-1200 mmTail length: 260-320 mmWeight: 37-55 kgDescription:The stripes on this animal differentiate it from Crocuta, the other hyaena known from Tanzania.Distribution:Preferring dry country like arid steppe, sub-desert, Acacia scrub, dry savannas, open montane habitats, and rocky escarpments, Hyaena hyaena is distributed throughout northern and northeastern Africa from the southern border of the Sahara desert up to the northern coastline and is also present in East Africa including Somalia, Kenya, Uganda and northern and central Tanzania. A checklist of the land mammals of the Tanganyika Territory and the Zanzibar Protectorate. Journal of the East African Natural History Society, 20(6):274-392.

Proteles cristata
(Sparrman, 1783)
Aardwolf
Figure 1. FMNH 286. Photograph by R. Banasiak.Figure 2. FMNH 95920. Photograph by P. Lai.
Type-Desc:
Resa Goda-Hopps-Udden., I. 1:581.
Type Locality:
English translation (Sparrman, 1786) of original locality: 'Agter-Bruntjes hoogte. . . Thich takes in the upper part of Kleine Visch-river, and is separated from Camdebo by Bruntjes hoogtens . . .'; listed in G. M. Allen (1939) as 'Near Little Fish River, Somerset East, Cape Colony' [South Africa].

descrip_text_raw:
Order: Carnivora > Family: Mustelidae > Genus: Aonyx > Species: capensis
Aonyx capensis
(Schinz, 1821)
African Clawless Otter
Figure 1. Photograph by R. Killackey.Figure 2. FMNH 73732. Photograph by P. Lai.
Type-Desc:
In G. Cuvier, Das Thierreich, 1:211.
Type Locality:
'Capischer otter. . Afrika' [South Africa, (former) Cape Province].
Measurements:Head and body: 720-910 mmTail length: 400-710 mmWeight: 13-28 kgDescription:This otter has unwebbed digits on the feet and very small nails.  The light coloration on the chin is not mottled, unlike the spot-necked otter.Distribution:Very patchy distribution throughout Africa south of the Sahara except in the central Congo basin from sea-level to 3,000 m, Aonyx capensis inhabits swamps, rivers, streams, lakes, marshes, and dams where prey is abundant, as well as estuaries and inshore sea near mangroves or tall cliffs.  (Kingdon, 1989, 1997)Figure 3. Key Reference:1. Kingdon, J. 1989. East African mammals: An atlas of evolution in Africa. (Carnivores). University of Chicago Press, Chicago, 3A:122-129.2. Ictonyx striatus
(Perry, 1810)
Striped Polecat or Zorilla
Figure 1. FMNH 26041. Photograph by R. Banasiak.Figure 2. FMNH 98347. Photograph by P. Lai.
Type-Desc:
Arcana, Mus. Nat. Hist. Signature Y, Fig. [41][1810].
Type Locality:
'South America'. This is clearly in error and Hollister (1918) fixed the type locality as 'Cape of Good Hope'. [South Africa].
Measurements:Head and body: 280-380 mmTail length: 200-300 mmWeight: 1.02-1.4 kgDescription:The black band over the top of the head differentiate the zorilla from the striped weasel.Distribution:Ictonyx striatus is common within cool, well-grazed grassy uplands and in steppe country throughout Africa south of the Sahara, except in moist forest and woodland zones and the tip of the Horn of Africa. (Kingdon, 1989, 1997)Figure 3. Key Reference:1. Kingdon, J. 1989. East African mammals: An atlas of evolution in Africa. (Carnivores). University of Chicago Press, Chicago, 3A:70-77. 2. (Schreber, 1776)
Honey Badger

Die Saugethiere, 3(18):pl. 125 [1776]; text, 3(26):450 [1777].
Type Locality:
'Vorgebirge der guten Hofnung' [South Africa, Western Cape Prov., Cape of Good Hope].
Measurements:Head and body: 600-770 mmTail length: 160-300 mmWeight: 7-13 kgDescription:This mustelid is recognized by the white forehead and white back, with black underside.Distribution:Ranging throughout all of Africa except for the driest areas of the Sahara north to the Mediterranean, Mellivora capensis can be commonly found in open woodland and patchy in forests, waterless desert steppe, Afro-alpine moorland and in coastal scrub. (Kingdon, 1997)

Poecilogale albinucha
(Gray, 1864)
African Striped Weasel
Figure 1. Photograph by R. Killackey.Figure 2. FMNH 26341. Photograph by P. Lai.
Type-Desc:
Proc. Zool. Soc. Lond., 1864:69, plate X.
Type Locality:
'it was without any habitat'. Fixed by Coetzee (1977b) as 'Cape Colony'.
Measurements:Head and body: 250-360 mmTail length: 130-230 mmWeight: 330-350 gDescription:The uninterupted white crown on the head distinguish this animal from the similar zorilla, which has a black stripe along the head.Distribution:Poecilogale albinucha is distributed from the southern half of the Congo basin and Angola to Tanzania and Mozambique with an isolated area in the southern Cape in South Africa, Namibia and Botswana where it is found in uplands with excessive grasslands and in high velds. (Kingdon, 1989, 1997)

descrip_text_raw:
Order: Carnivora > Family: Nandiniidae > Genus: Nandinia > Species: binotata
Nandinia binotata
(Gray, 1830)
African Palm Civet
Figure 1. FMNH 25305. Photograph by R. Banasiak.Figure 2. FMNH 151366. Photograph by P. Lai.
Type-Desc:
Gray, J. E. 1828-1830 [-1924]. Spilcilegia zoological; or original figures and short systematic descriptions of new and unfigured animals. London, 1:1-8[1828]; 2:9-12[1830]; 3:1-13[1924].
Type Locality:
'Africa, Ashantee' [Ghana; Ashanti Region; aproximately at 6°55'N 0°32'E].
Measurements:Total length: 762-1011 mmHead and body: 450-580 mmTail length: 500-620 mmHindfoot length: 70-89 mmEar length: 35-40 mmWeight: 1.7-2.1 kgDescription:Look for two very pale spots on the shoulder (these can be very subtle) and a very reduced auditory bulla.  The vocalizations of this animal can sound much like an owl.Distribution:A common species found in rainforests and cultivation mosaics that follow partial or extensive clearance of the forest throughout most areas of East Africa, Nandinia binotata is distributed throughout tropical Africa from Sierra Leone along the coast to northern Angola and over to western Uganda and Tanzania and southern Kenya and with a scattered distribution area along the montane areas from the EAM range down into Zimbabwe. (Kingdon, 1989, 1997)Figure 3. Key Reference:1. Kingdon, J. 1989. East African mammals: An atlas of evolution in Africa. (Carnivores). University of Chicago Press, Chicago, 3A:168-175. 2. Kingdon, J. 1997. The Kingdon field guide to African mammals, AP Natural World Academic Press, Harcourt Brace & Company, San Diego, p. 275.3. Nowak, R. M. 1999. Walker's Mammals of the World. Sixth ed. Johns Hopkins University Press, Baltimore, 1:748-749, 756-757.4. Swynnerton, G. H., and R. W. Hayman. 1951. A checklist of the land mammals of the Tanganyika Territory and the Zanzibar Protectorate. Journal of the East African Natural History Society, 20(6):274-392.
Description: Look for two very pale spots on the shoulder (these can be very subtle) and a very reduced auditory bulla. The vocalizations of this animal can sound much like an owl.

Civettictis civetta
(Schreber, 1776)
African Civet
Figure 1. Photograph by D. De Luca.Figure 2. FMNH 153696. Photograph by P. Lai.
Type-Desc:
Die Saugethiere, 3(16):pl. 111 [1776]; text 3(24):418, 3:index, p. 587 [1777].
Type Locality:
'Guinea, Kongo, das Vorgebirge der guten Hofnung und Aethiopien', restriced by Allen (1924:117) to 'Guinea'.
Measurements:Total length: 1020-1150 mmHead and body: 680-890 mmTail length: 445-463 mmHindfoot length: 124-125 mmEar length: 50-56 mmWeight: 7-20 kgDescription:A nocturnal carnivore with strong scent glands in the anal region.  The civet is omnivorous eating both plants and animals.Distribution:Distributed throughout most of Africa south of the Sahara, except in areas of the Horn of Africa and Namibia, Botswana, and South Africa, Civettictis civetta is found in lowland and montane forests, cultivation, fallow, marsh, grassy savannas, reed beds, and cane breaks of elephant grass. (Kingdon, 1989, 1997)Figure 3. Key Reference:1. Kingdon, J. 1989. East African mammals: An atlas of evolution in Africa. (Carnivores). University of Chicago Press, Chicago, 3A:158-167. 2. Sixth ed. Johns Hopkins University Press, Baltimore, 1:748-749, 750-751.
Description: A nocturnal carnivore with strong scent glands in the anal region. The civet is omnivorous eating both plants and animals.Distribution:

Genetta angolensis
Bocage, 1882
Angolan Genet
Figure 1. FMNH 163777. Photograph by R. Banasiak.
Type-Desc:
J. Sci. Math. Phys. Nat. Lisboa, ser. 1, 9:29.
Type Locality:
'Calcuimba' [placed in Angola, Caconda (13°47'S, 15°08'E)].
Measurements:Head and body: 440-480 mmTail length: 380-430 mmWeight: 1.3-2 kgDescription:The genets are recognized by the ringed long tail and spots in rows on the side of the animal.  There is only one longitudinal stripe along the back of the animal.Distribution:Genetta angolensis can be found in the Miombo woodlands from Angola to Mozambique and up to Tanzania preferring moister woodlands, riverine vegetation and forest galleries. (Kingdon, 1997)Figure 2. Key Reference:1. Kingdon, J. 1997. The Kingdon field guide to African mammals, AP Natural World Academic Press, Harcourt Brace & Company, San Diego, p. 269.2. Nowak, R. descrip_text_raw:
Order: Carnivora > Family: Viverridae > Genus: Genetta > Species: genetta
Genetta genetta
(Linnaeus, 1758)
Common Genet
Figure 1. FMNH 127823. Photograph by R. Banasiak.
Type-Desc:
Syst. Nat., 10th ed., 1:45.
Type Locality:
'oriente juxta rivos', restricted by Linnaeus (1766) to 'oriente juxta rivos, Hispania', later listed by Thomas (1911a) as 'Spain'. Cabrera (1914), synonymizing G. peninsulae, further restricted the type locality to 'El Pardo, cerca de Madrid' [Spain, El Pardo, near Madrid (40°32'N, 3°46'W)].
Measurements:Head and body: 420-630 mmTail length: 390-530 mmHindfoot length: 70-97 mmWeight: 1-2.3 kgDescription:The genets are recognized by the ringed long tail and spots in rows on the side of the animal.  There is only one longitudinal stripe along the back of the animal.Distribution:Genetta genetta is adapted to arid areas from the north-African coastline down along the west coast to Senegal and east to Somalia, Kenya and Tanzania with a second area from Angola to the Congo down to South Africa. This species inhabits drier bush and woodlands to sparsely bushed near-desert and rocky, hill country where they can live without water. (Kingdon, 1989, 1997)Figure 2. Key Reference:1. Kingdon, J. 1989. East African mammals: An atlas of evolution in Africa. (Carnivores). University of Chicago Press, Chicago, 3A:137, 142-143.2. Kingdon, J. 1997. Journal of the East African Natural History Society, 20(6):274-392.
Description: The genets are recognized by the ringed long tail and spots in rows on the side of the animal. There is only one longitudinal stripe along the back of the animal.

Order: Carnivora > Family: Viverridae > Genus: Genetta > Species: maculata
Genetta maculata
(Gray, 1830)
Rusty-spotted Genet
Figure 1. Photograph by D. De Luca.Figure 2. FMNH 85993. Photograph by R. Banasiak.
Type-Desc:
Gray, J. E. 1828-1830 [-1924]. Spilcilegia zoological; or original figures and short systematic descriptions of new and unfigured animals. London, 1:1-8[1828]; 2:9-12[1830]; 3:1-13[1924].

'in Africa Boreali'. Subsequently redefined by Gaubert et al. (2003b) as '6 km from Hirna (Harrar Road, 2180m), Ethiopia', following designation of a neotype.
Measurements:Head and body: 400-550 mmTail length: 400-540 mmWeight: 1.2-3.1 kgDescription:The genets are recognized by the ringed long tail and spots in rows on the side of the animal.  There is only one longitudinal stripe along the back of the animal.Distribution:Widely distributed throughout the central part of Africa from the Cameroons and Gabon in the west over to Ethiopia, Somalia (except the Horn of Africa), and Kenya in the east and down in the Dem. Rep. of Congo and Tanzania, Genetta maculata can be found in rainforests, riverine vegetation, secondary growth, moist woodlands, cultivation, suburbia, reed beds, swamp forests, and grassy savannas. (Kingdon, 1989, 1997)Figure 3. Key Reference:1. Kingdon, J. 1989. East African mammals: An atlas of evolution in Africa. (Carnivores). University of Chicago Press, Chicago, 3A:137, 147-151.2. Genetta servalina
Pucheran, 1855
Servaline Genet
Figure 1. Photograph by D. De Luca.Figure 2. FMNH 145230. Photograph by R. Banasiak.
Type-Desc:
Rev. Mag. Zool. Paris, 7(2):154.
Type Locality:
'Gabon'.
Measurements:Head and body: 410-500 mmTail length: 350-440 mmHindfoot length: 70-80 mmWeight: 1-1.12 kgDescription:The genets are recognized by the ringed long tail and spots in rows on the side of the animal.  There is only one longitudinal stripe along the back of the animal.Distribution:A true forest species, Genetta servalina can be found in rain, lowland, and montane forests throughout the Congo basin from Nigeria, the Cameroons, and Gabon over to Uganda, southern Kenya, and northern Tanzania with a discontinuous distribution in the Southern Highlands in Tanzania. Description: The genets are recognized by the ringed long tail and spots in rows on the side of the animal. There is only one longitudinal stripe along the back of the animal.

Equus burchelli
(Gray, 1824)
Burchell's Zebra
Figure 1. Photograph by B. Stanley.Figure 2. FMNH 95829. Photograph by R. Banasiak.
Type-Desc:
Zool. J., 1:247.
Type Locality:
'The flat parts near the Cape', now identified as South Africa, Northern Cape Prov., Kuruman Dist., Little Klibbolikhonni Fontein (Grubb, 1999:16).
Measurements:Head and body: 2170-2460 mmTail length: 470-565 mmWeight: 175-322 kgDescription:The horse was introduced to Tanzania, while the zebra is a common resident of the grasslands.Distribution:Found in grasslands, steppes, savannas, and woodlands, Equus burchelli is distributed from the Sudan and Ethiopia down through East Africa to northern South Africa and across the Angola and Namibia. (Kingdon, 1997)

descrip_text_raw:
Order: Perissodactyla > Family: Rhinocerotidae > Genus: Diceros > Species: bicornis
Diceros bicornis
(Linnaeus, 1758)
Black Rhinoceros
Figure 1. Photograph by B. Stanley.Figure 2. FMNH 127851. Photograph by R. Banasiak.
Type-Desc:
Syst. Nat., 10th ed., 1:56.
Type Locality:
'Habitat in India', now identified as South Africa, Western Cape Prov., Cape of Good Hope.
Measurements:Head and body: 3000-3750 mmTail length: 700 mmWeight: 996-1362 kgDescription:The animal can stand 150 cm at the shoulder and weigh up to 1800 kg.  They usually have two horns, the front one larger than the rear.  The rhino browses trees with a prehensile upper lip.  They have poor vision but good hearing and sense of smell.   Gestation is roughly 450 days.  Because of demand for the horn of this unique animal, Tanzania's remaining rhinos are under extreme threat.Distribution:With several different fragmented distribution areas, Diceros bicornis can be found favoring thicket and savanna edges with woody regrowth and numerous shrubs in the Cameroons, Chad and the Central African Republic, a small, isolated part of southern Sudan, throughout Tanzania, Kenya, Burundi, and Rwanda down to South Africa and a small area along the west coast in northern Namibia. (Kingdon, 1997)
Figure 3. Key Reference:1. Kingdon, J. 1989. East African mammals: An atlas of evolution in Africa. (Large Mammals). University of Chicago Press, Chicago, 3B:92-105.2. Kingdon, J. 1997. The Kingdon field guide to African mammals, AP Natural World Academic Press, Harcourt Brace & Company, San Diego, p. 319-320.3. Nowak, R. M. 1999. Walker's Mammals of the World. Sixth ed. Johns Hopkins University Press, Baltimore, 2:1028-1030, 1034-1037.4. Swynnerton, G. H., and R. W. Hayman. 1951. A checklist of the land mammals of the Tanganyika Territory and the Zanzibar Protectorate. Journal of the East African Natural History Society, 20(6):274-392.
Description: The animal can stand 150 cm at the shoulder and weigh up to 1800 kg. They usually have two horns, the front one larger than the rear. The rhino browses trees with a prehensile upper lip. They have poor vision but good hearing and sense of smell. Gestation is roughly 450 days. Because of demand for the horn of this unique animal, Tanzania's remaining rhinos are under extreme threat.
type_locality: 'Habitat in India', now identified as South Africa, Western Cape Prov., Cape of Good Hope.

descrip_text_raw:
Order: Artiodactyla > Family: Bovidae > Genus: Alcelaphus > Species: buselaphus
Alcelaphus buselaphus
(Pallas, 1766)
Hartebeest
Figure 1. Photograph by B. Stanley.Figure 2. FMNH 20660, 127893. Photograph by R. Banasiak.
Type-Desc:
Misc. Zool., p. 7.
Type Locality:
No locality cited but the name is based on "Le bubale" of Buffon, "en Barbarie & dans toutes les parties septentrionales de l'Afrique", and on other sources. Restricted to Barbary by designation of the "Vache de Barbarie" of Perrault as the lectotype (Ruxton and Schwarz, 1929:575). Further restricted to Morocco (Lydekker, 1914a:5).
Measurements:Head and body: 1770-2150 mmTail length: 300 mmWeight: 116-218 kgDescription:The hartebeest is recognizable by its long narrow face and horns set on pedicles of the skull.  They are common inhabitants of grasslands.Figure 3. Key Reference:1. Kingdon, J. 1989. East African mammals: An atlas of evolution in Africa. (Large Mammals). University of Chicago Press, Chicago, 3D:502-523.2. Kingdon, J. 1997. The Kingdon field guide to African mammals, AP Natural World Academic Press, Harcourt Brace & Company, San Diego, p. 428-431.3. Nowak, R. M. 1999. Walker's Mammals of the World. Sixth ed. Johns Hopkins University Press, Baltimore, 2:1135, 1181-1183.

descrip_text_raw:
Order: Artiodactyla > Family: Bovidae > Genus: Bos > Species: taurus
Bos taurus
Linnaeus, 1758
Cows/Ankole Cattle
Figure 1. Photograph by B. Stanley and R. Banasiak.Figure 2. FMNH 92911, 140835. Photograph by R. Banasiak.
Type-Desc:
Syst. Nat., 10th ed., 1:71.
Type Locality:
Linnaeus (1758) stated 'habitat in Poloniae depressis graminosis ferus Urus' 'Urus' applies to the aurochs because Linneaus' only source was Caesar in his 'Gallic Wars' where the aurochs is described (Lydekker, 1912). Other authors have used the name 'Urus' for the European Bison Bison bonasus, in the 18th Century thought to be the wild form of domestic cattle. Thomas (1911a:154) proposed to restrict the type locality to Sweden, Upsala, applying taurus to domestic cattle.
Measurements:Weight: 450-1000 kgDescription:The cow is a familiar species and is found all over the world as a domesticated farm animal, providing meat and milk to humans.  The cylindrical shape of the horns and the blocky shape of the back of the skull differentiate it from other bovids with horns protruding laterally from the skull, such as buffalo and wildebeest.Key Reference:1. Kingdon, J. 1989. East African mammals: An atlas of evolution in Africa. (Large Mammals). University of Chicago Press, Chicago, 3C:54-55.2. Nowak, R. M. 1999. Walker's Mammals of the World. Sixth ed. Johns Hopkins University Press, Baltimore, 2:1135, 1153-1157.

Order: Artiodactyla > Family: Bovidae > Genus: Connochaetes > Species: taurinus
Connochaetes taurinus
(Burchell, 1824)
Blue Wildbeest
Figure 1. Photograph by B. Stanley.Figure 2. FMNH 34555, 127905. Photograph by R. Banasiak and P Lai.
Type-Desc:
Burchell, W. J. 1822-1824 [1822-23]. Travels in the interior of Southern Africa. Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, Brown, and Green, London, 2 volumes [vol, 2 published in 1823, dated 1824].
Type Locality:
Apparently "Kosi Fountain", but lectotype came from South Africe, North West Prov., Vryburg Dist., "Chue Spring, Maadji Mtn [Klein Heuningvlei]"; see Grubb (1999).
Measurements:Head and body: 1940-2090 mmTail length: 450-560 mmWeight: 118-270 kgDescription:The wildebeest is a familiar animal found in short grasslands and famous for migrating.Figure 3. Key Reference:1. Kingdon, J. 1989. East African mammals: An atlas of evolution in Africa. (Large Mammals). University of Chicago Press, Chicago, 3D:524-537.2. Kingdon, J. 1997. The Kingdon field guide to African mammals, AP Natural World Academic Press, Harcourt Brace & Company, San Diego, p. 431-434.3. Nowak, R. M. 1999. Walker's Mammals of the World. Sixth ed. Johns Hopkins University Press, Baltimore, 2:1135, 1184-1186.

(Gunther, 1884)
Thomson's Gazelle
Figure 1. Photograph by B. Stanley.Figure 2. FMNH 29614. Photograph by R. Banasiak.
Type-Desc:
Ann. Mag. Nat. Hist., ser. 5, 14:427.
Type Locality:
"the range of country from Kilimanjaro to Baringo and at various heights above 6000' [1829 m]"; restricted to "Kilimanjaro district" (Lydekker, 1914b:84) in Kenya (G. M. Allen, 1939:526).
Measurements:Head and body: 890-1070 mmTail length: 190-260 mmWeight: 13-28.7 kgDescription:The gazelles are common residents of grassland and woodland areas.Figure 3. Key Reference:1. Johns Hopkins University Press, Baltimore, 2:1135, 1199-1202.

Type-Desc:

Type Locality:
'Inconnue'; now thought to be South Africa, Western Cape Prov., Plettenberg Bay (Grubb, 1999).
Measurements:Head and body: 1900-2400 mmTail length: 370-480 mmWeight: 223-300 kgDescription:These beautiful antelope are characterized by the horns that arc back from the skull and the black and white markings on the face.Figure 3. Journal of the East African Natural History Society, 20(6):274-392.

(Linnaeus, 1766)
Puku
Figure 1. FMNH 26917, 38164. Photograph by R. Banasiak.
Type-Desc:
Missionary Travels and Researches in South Africa, p. 256.
Type Locality:
'Thirty or forty miles above Libonta'; since identified as Zambia, Barotseland, Chobe Valley, near Libonda at 40°0'S, 23°15'E.
Measurements:Head and body: 1260-1420 mmTail length: 280-320 mmWeight: 48-91 kgDescription:The Puku was historically more widespread than it is now and is currently found only in small populations in the central and southern part of the country.Figure 2. Journal of the East African Natural History Society, 20(6):274-392.
Description:
Order: Artiodactyla > Family: Bovidae > Genus: Kobus > Species: vardonii
Kobus vardonii
(Linnaeus, 1766)
Puku
Figure 1. FMNH 26917, 38164. Photograph by R. Banasiak.
Type-Desc:
Missionary Travels and Researches in South Africa, p. 256.
Type Locality:
'Thirty or forty miles above Libonta'; since identified as Zambia, Barotseland, Chobe Valley, near Libonda at 40°0'S, 23°15'E.
Measurements:Head and body: 1260-1420 mmTail length: 280-320 mmWeight: 48-91 kgDescription:The Puku was historically more widespread than it is now and is currently found only in small populations in the central and southern part of the country.Figure 2. Key Reference:1. Kingdon, J. 1989. East African mammals: An atlas of evolution in Africa. (Large Mammals). University of Chicago Press, Chicago, 3C:382-383.2. Kingdon, J. 1997. The Kingdon field guide to African mammals, AP Natural World Academic Press, Harcourt Brace & Company, San Diego, p. 404-405.3. Nowak, R. M. 1999. Walker's Mammals of the World. Sixth ed. Johns Hopkins University Press, Baltimore, 2:1135, 1166-1170.4. Swynnerton, G. H., and R. W. Hayman. 1951. A checklist of the land mammals of the Tanganyika Territory and the Zanzibar Protectorate. Journal of the East African Natural History Society, 20(6):274-392.

descrip_text_raw:
Order: Artiodactyla > Family: Bovidae > Genus: Litocranius > Species: walleri
Litocranius walleri
(Brooke, 1879)
Gerenuk
Figure 1. Photograph by B. Stanley.Figure 2. FMNH 26903, 26984. Photograph by R. Banasiak.
Type-Desc:
Proc. Zool. Soc. Lond., 1878:929, pl. 56 [1879].
Type Locality:
"Mainland of Africa, north of the island of Zanzibar, about lat. 30°S and long. 38°E" and therefore apparently in Kenya, but shown to be correctly "Somalia, coast near Juba River" by Sclater and Thomas (1898) and Moreau et al. (1946) and more specifically, the vicinity of Chisimayo (Grubb, 2002).
Measurements:Head and body: 1400-1600 mmTail length: 220-350 mmWeight: 28.5-52 kgDescription:Another common name for this long-necked antelope is Waller's gazelle.Figure 3. Key Reference:1. Kingdon, J. 1989. East African mammals: An atlas of evolution in Africa. (Large Mammals). University of Chicago Press, Chicago, 3D:426-437.2. Kingdon, J. 1997. The Kingdon field guide to African mammals, AP Natural World Academic Press, Harcourt Brace & Company, San Diego, p. 416-419.3. Nowak, R. M. 1999. Walker's Mammals of the World. Sixth ed. Johns Hopkins University Press, Baltimore, 2:1135, 1197-1199.

descrip_text_raw:
Order: Artiodactyla > Family: Bovidae > Genus: Madoqua > Species: kirkii
Madoqua kirkii
(Gunther, 1880)
Kirk's Dik-dik
Figure 1. Photograph by B. Stanley.Figure 2. FMNH 27273, 156114. Photograph by R. Banasiak.
Type-Desc:
Proc. Zool. Soc. Lond., 1880:17.
Type Locality:
Somalia, 'near Brava, in the South Somali country'.
Measurements:Head and body: 590-720 mmTail length: 45-56 mmHindfoot length: 160-190 mmWeight: 3.8-7.2 kgDescription:The white eyering with a black gland in the lower region and the tuft of hair on the top of the head are defining characteristics.Figure 3. Key Reference:1. Kingdon, J. 1989. East African mammals: An atlas of evolution in Africa. (Large Mammals). University of Chicago Press, Chicago, 3C:242-261.2. Kingdon, J. 1997. The Kingdon field guide to African mammals, AP Natural World Academic Press, Harcourt Brace & Company, San Diego, p. 394, 396.3. Nowak, R. M. 1999. Walker's Mammals of the World. Sixth ed. Journal of the East African Natural History Society, 20(6):274-392.

Order: Artiodactyla > Family: Bovidae > Genus: Nanger > Species: granti
Nanger granti
(Brooke, 1872)
Grant's Gazelle
Figure 1. Photograph by B. Stanley.Figure 2. FMNH 29604, 29609. Photograph by R. Banasiak.
Type-Desc:
Proc. Zool. Soc. Lond., 1872:602.
Type Locality:
Tanzania, "Western Kinyenye, in Ugogo".
Measurements:Head and body: 1400-1660 mmTail length: 200-280 mmWeight: 38-81.5 kgDescription:The gazelles are common residents of grassland and woodland areas.Figure 3. Key Reference:1. Kingdon, J. 1989. East African mammals: An atlas of evolution in Africa. (Large Mammals). University of Chicago Press, Chicago, 3D:414-421.2. Kingdon, J. 1997. The Kingdon field guide to African mammals, AP Natural World Academic Press, Harcourt Brace & Company, San Diego, p. 413-415.3. Nowak, R. M. 1999. Walker's Mammals of the World. Sixth ed. Johns Hopkins University Press, Baltimore, 2:1135, 1199-1202.

(Von Dueben, 1846)
Suni
Figure 1. Photograph by C&M Stuart.Figure 2. FMNH 17794. Photograph by R. Banasiak.
Type-Desc:
In Sundevall, Ofv. K. Svenska Vet.-Akad. Forhandl., Stockholm, 3(7):221.
Type Locality:
'in Chapani (Anglis French island) occisa insula prope Zanzibar in Lat. Austr. 6°9', Long. Orient. 39°14' a Greenwich sita, fructibus dense tecta et fonte irrigata' (Tanzania, Chapani Isl, 3 km from Zanzibar).

University of Chicago Press, Chicago, 3C:192-201.2. Kingdon, J. 1997. The Kingdon field guide to African mammals, AP Natural World Academic Press, Harcourt Brace & Company, San Diego, p. 385-386.3. A checklist of the land mammals of the Tanganyika Territory and the Zanzibar Protectorate. Journal of the East African Natural History Society, 20(6):274-392.

descrip_text_raw:
Order: Artiodactyla > Family: Bovidae > Genus: Oreotragus > Species: oreotragus
Oreotragus oreotragus
(Zimmermann, 1783)
Klipspringer
Figure 1. Photograph by R. Banasiak.Figure 2. FMNH 7470, 19582. Photograph by R. Banasiak.
Type-Desc:
Zimmermann, E. A. W., von. 1778-1783. Geographische Geschichte des Menschen, und der allgemein verbreiteten vierfussigen Thiere, nebst einer Hieher gehorigen zoologischen Weltcharte. Vol. 2. Geographische Geschichte des Menschen, und der vierfussigen Thiere. Zweiter Band. Enthalt ein vollstandiges. Verzeichniss aller bekannten Quadrupeden. Weygandschen Buchhandlung, Leipzig, 3:1-276.
Type Locality:
'Die Caffern'; now known to be South Africa, Western Cape Prov., Cape Dist., False Bay (Grubb, 1999).
Measurements:Head and body: 750-900 mmTail length: 64-105 mmWeight: 8-18 kgDescription:The bristly hairs and truncated tips of the hooves help to identify this very agile antelope.Figure 3. Key Reference:1. Kingdon, J. 1989. East African mammals: An atlas of evolution in Africa. (Large Mammals). University of Chicago Press, Chicago, 3C:231-241.2. Kingdon, J. 1997. The Kingdon field guide to African mammals, AP Natural World Academic Press, Harcourt Brace & Company, San Diego, p. 390-392.3. Nowak, R. M. 1999. Walker's Mammals of the World. Sixth ed. Journal of the East African Natural History Society, 20(6):274-392.

Oryx beisa
(Ruppell, 1835)
Beisa
Figure 1. Photograph by B. Stanley.Figure 2. FMNH 1405, 22256. Photograph by R. Banasiak.
Type-Desc:
Neue Wirbelthiere z. d. Fauna Abyssinien gehorig, Saugeth., p. 14, pl. 5.
Type Locality:
Eritrea, "in den Niederungen der Küstenlandschaft bei Massaua" (Red Sea coast west of Massawa).
Measurements:Head and body: 1530-1700 mmTail length: 470 mmWeight: 116-209 kgDescription:The long straight horns (in both sexes) and the dark markings on the face help to identify this large antelope.Figure 3. Key Reference:1. Kingdon, J. 1989. East African mammals: An atlas of evolution in Africa. (Large Mammals). University of Chicago Press, Chicago, 3D:579-587.2. Kingdon, J. 1997. Johns Hopkins University Press, Baltimore, 2:1135, 1175-1178.

Ourebia ourebi
(Zimmermann, 1783)
Oribi
Figure 1. FMNH 66874, 127975. Photograph by R. Banasiak.
Type-Desc:
Zimmermann, E. A. W., von. 1778-1783. Geographische Geschichte des Menschen, und der allgemein verbreiteten vierfussigen Thiere, nebst einer Hieher gehorigen zoologischen Weltcharte. Vol. 2. Type Locality:
'Bewohnt die Cafferen' (South Africa, Eastern Cape Prov., Kaffraria); since restricted to one of the syntypical localities: South Africa, Eastern Cape Prov., Somerset East Dist., Bruintjieshoogte (Grubb, 1999).

descrip_text_raw:
Order: Artiodactyla > Family: Bovidae > Genus: Ovis > Species: aries
Ovis aries
Linnaeus, 1758
Red Sheep
Figure 1. Photograph by B. Stanley.Figure 2. FMNH 57540. Photograph by R. Banasiak.
Type-Desc:
Syst. Nat., 10th ed., 1:70.
Type Locality:
'Habitat in siccis apricis calidis'; identified as Sweden by Thomas (1911a:153); domesticated stock.

Type-Desc:
Syst. Nat., 10th ed., 1:70.
Type Locality:
Habitat in Africa'; based on a specimen seen by Grimm in the fort at Cape Town (Thomas, 1911a:153) so now known to be South Africa, Western Cape Prov., Cape Town.
Measurements:Head and body: 700-1150 mmTail length: 75-195 mmWeight: 11-25.5 kgDescription:The horns that are found only in males and that stick off the head at an angle from the plane of the face help to distinguish this duiker from forest duikers.Key Reference:1. Anomalurus derbianus
(Gray, 1842)
Lord Derby's Scaly-tailed Squirrel
Figure 1. FMNH 128. Photograph by R. Banasiak.Figure 2. FMNH 88208. Photograph by P. Lai.
Type-Desc:
Ann. Mag. Nat. Hist., [ser. 1], 10:262.
Type Locality:
'Sierra Leone'.
Measurements:Head and body: 270-379 mmTail length: 220-284 mmHindfoot length: 48-65 mmWeight: 450-1090 gDescription:The flying squirrel is identified by the furred membrane that stretches from the front to the back legs and the small patch of scales on the underside of the base of the tail.Distribution:Ranging from Sierra Leone in the west to Uganda in the east down through the Eastern Arc Mountains to southern Tanzania, Anomalurus derbianus is found at altitudes up to 2,400 m in moist rainforests to dry woodlands. (Kingdon, 1984, 1997)

Journal of the East African Natural History Society, 20(6):274-392.

descrip_text_raw:
Order: Rodentia > Family: Bathyergidae > Genus: Heliophobius > Species: argenteocinereus
Heliophobius argenteocinereus
Peters, 1846
Silvery Mole-rat
Figure 1. Photograph by B. Stanley.Figure 2. FMNH 158272. Photograph by R. Banasiak.
Type-Desc:
Bericht Verhandl. K. Preuss. Akad. Wiss. Berlin, 11:259.
Type Locality:
Mozambique, Tete (on the Zambezi River).
Measurements:Total length: 140-193 mmHead and body: 100-200 mmTail length: 15-40 mmHindfoot length: 27-35 mmEar length: 2-5 mmWeight: 142-168 gDescription:This burrowing rodent is differentiated from Cryptomys, another burrower, by the long hair length.  These animals commonly have white patches on the head and other parts of the body.
Distribution:Preferring lower altitudes up to 1,500 m in drier and warmer habitats like in the central and eastern Miombo woodlands, Heliophobius argenteocinereus can be found in sandy soils on rocky hillsides, in the open plains or in woodlands from Tanzania to the Dem. Rep. of Congo, Malawi, Zambia and northern Mozambique. (Kingdon, 1984, 1997)
Figure 3. Key Reference:1. Kingdon, J. 1984. East African mammals: An atlas of evolution in Africa. (Hares and Rodents). University of Chicago Press, Chicago, 2B:486-488.2. Kingdon, J. 1997. Johns Hopkins University Press, Baltimore, 2:1635-1636, 1639-1640.4. Swynnerton, G. H., and R. W. Hayman. 1951. A checklist of the land mammals of the Tanganyika Territory and the Zanzibar Protectorate. Journal of the East African Natural History Society, 20(6):274-392.
Description: This burrowing rodent is differentiated from Cryptomys, another burrower, by the long hair length. These animals commonly have white patches on the head and other parts of the body.

descrip_text_raw:
Order: Rodentia > Family: Muridae > Genus: Dasymys > Species: incomtus
Dasymys incomtus
(Sundevall, 1847)
Common Dasymys
Figure 1. Photograph by B. Stanley.Figure 2. FMNH 28638. Photograph by P. Lai.
Type-Desc:
Ofv. K. Svenska Vet.-Akad. Forhandl, Stockholm, 1846, 3:120.
Type Locality:
South Africa, 'Caffraria prope Portum Natal,' (= Durban, KwaZulu-Natal); 29°15'S, 31°01'E (W. Verheyen et al., 2003).
Measurements:Total length: 152-323 mmHead and body: 124-190 mmTail length: 107-185 mmHindfoot length: 27-33 mmEar length: 16-21 mmWeight: 82-125 gDescription:The common name of this rodent comes from its very shaggy fur.  It inhabits wet marshy areas.Distribution:Dasymys incomtus prefers wetter grassy areas, highland bogs and marshes of sub-Saharan Africa from the Dem. Rep. of Congo to Kenya and south to South Africa up to 4,000 m. (Kingdon, 1984, 1997) (Wilson and Reeder, 2005)Figure 3. Key Reference:1. Kingdon, J. 1984. East African mammals: An atlas of evolution in Africa. (Insectivores and Bats). University of Chicago Press, Chicago, 2B:606-607.2. Kingdon, J. 1997. The Kingdon field guide to African mammals, AP Natural World Academic Press, Harcourt Brace & Company, San Diego, p. 209-210.3. Nowak, R. M. 1999. Walker's Mammals of the World. Sixth ed. Johns Hopkins University Press, Baltimore, 2:1344-1346, 1602.4. Swynnerton, G. H., and R. W. Hayman. 1951. A checklist of the land mammals of the Tanganyika Territory and the Zanzibar Protectorate. Journal of the East African Natural History Society, 20(6):274-392.5. Wilson, D. E., and D. M. Reeder (eds.). 2005. Mammal species of the world, a taxonomic and geographic reference, Third ed. The Johns Hopkins University Press, Baltimore, 2:1316.
Description: The common name of this rodent comes from its very shaggy fur. It inhabits wet marshy areas.

descrip_text_raw:
Order: Rodentia > Family: Muridae > Genus: Dasymys > Species: sua
Dasymys sua
W. Verheyen, Hulselmans, Dierckx, Colyn, Leirs, and E. Verheyen, 2003
Tanzanian Dasymys
Type-Desc:
Verheyen, W. N., J. L. J. Hulselmans, T. Dierckx, M. Colyn, H. Leirs, and E. Verheyen. 2003. A craniometric and genetic approach to the systematics of the genus Dasymys Peters, 1875, selection of a neotype and description of three new taxa (Rodentia, Muridae, Africa).  Bulletin de L'Institut Royal des Sciences Naturelles de Belgique, Biologie, 73:27-71.
Type Locality:
E Tanzania, Mbete (06°52'S, 37°41'E, as per W. Verheyen et al., 2003:41), near Morogoro, on flanks of the Uluguru Range (Kitundu Forest), 1540 m.
Measurements:Head and body: 124-190 mmTail length: 107-185 mmHindfoot length: 27-33 mmWeight: 82-125 gDescription:The common name of this rodent comes from its very shaggy fur.  It inhabits wet marshy areas.Distribution:Restricted to the Morogoro Region in eastern Tanzania, Dasymys sua is found in wet marshy areas including moss and sedge bogs from 400-1,600 m. (Kingdon, 1997) (Wilson and Reeder, 2005)
Key Reference:1. Kingdon, J. 1984. East African mammals: An atlas of evolution in Africa. (Insectivores and Bats). University of Chicago Press, Chicago, 2B:606-607.2. Kingdon, J. 1997. Johns Hopkins University Press, Baltimore, 2:1344-1346, 1602.4. Wilson, D. E., and D. M. Reeder (eds.). 2005. Mammal species of the world, a taxonomic and geographic reference, Third ed. The Johns Hopkins University Press, Baltimore, 2:1316.
Description: The common name of this rodent comes from its very shaggy fur. It inhabits wet marshy areas.

descrip_text_raw:
Order: Rodentia > Family: Muridae > Genus: Gerbilliscus > Species: boehmi
Gerbilliscus boehmi
(Noack, 1887)
Boehm's Gerbil
Figure 1. FMNH 27310. Photograph by R. Banasiak.
Type-Desc:
Zool. Jahrb. Syst., 2:241.
Type Locality:
Dem. Rep. Congo, Katanga Province, Marungu, Qua Mpala (see Ansell, 1978, and Hill and Carter, 1941, for placement of type locality in S Dem. Rep. Congo; it has also been identified as N Zambia [G. M. Allen, 1939; Bates, 1988]).
Measurements:Head and body: 155-185 mmTail length: 210-245 mmHindfoot length: 43-44 mmWeight: 60-125 gDescription:These rodents are sometimes called the naked-soled gerbils, because of the lack of hair on the soles of the hind feet.  Differentiation among the different species within this genus is difficult.Figure 2. Key Reference:1. Kingdon, J. 1984. East African mammals: An atlas of evolution in Africa. (Hares and Rodents). University of Chicago Press, Chicago, 2B:508-513.2. Kingdon, J. 1997. The Kingdon field guide to African mammals, AP Natural World Academic Press, Harcourt Brace & Company, San Diego, p. 194-195.3. Nowak, R. M. 1999. Walker's Mammals of the World. Sixth ed. Johns Hopkins University Press, Baltimore, 2:1344-1346, 1449-1451.

descrip_text_raw:
Order: Rodentia > Family: Muridae > Genus: Hylomyscus > Species: anselli
Hylomyscus anselli
Bishop, 1979
Ansell's Hylomyscus
Figure 1. Photograph by B. Stanley.Figure 2. FMNH 171360. Photograph by R. Banasiak.
Type-Desc:
Bishop, I. R. 1979. Notes on Praomys (Hylomyscus) in eastern Africa. Mammalia, 43:521-530.
Type Locality:
Zambia, Mwinilunga District, Jimbe Stream, 10°57'S, 24°05'E.
Measurements:Head and body: 71-120 mmTail length: 100-172 mmHindfoot length: 19.5-22 mmWeight: 8-42 gDescription:Ansell's Hylomyscus (Hylomyscus anselli) is a small wood mouse with a slightly darker fawn colour on the dorsal pelage and a light grey-white on the ventral underside (Figure 1). H. anselli also has a short incisive (palatal) foramina with a longer bony palate (Figure 3). (Bishop, 1979)Ansell's Hylomyscus is a good climber and a common resident of the montane forests of north-central Zambia to the Ufipa Plateau in western Tanzania.  The geographic distribution of H. anselli overlaps with that of Praomys jacksoni which is the species it is most commonly confused with. (Carleton & Stanley, 2005) Abbreviations: ab, auditory bulla; ex, exoccipital; hp, hamular process of squamosal; if, incisive foramina; ms, mastoid bulla; pa, parietal; pal, palate; pgf, postglenoid foramen; sq, squamosal; ssf, subsquamosal fenestra.
Figure 3. Incisvie (palatal) foramina of H. anselli (FMNH 171360), left, shorter length just above first molar; and H. denniae (FMNH 144614), right, longer length just past first molar. Photograph by R. Banasiak.Comparisons: Hylomyscus anselli can be differentiated from H. denniae by the presence of only 6 mammary glands instead of 8 (pectoral pair of teats are absent). H. anselli has a well defined subsquamosal fenestra in the otic region (Figure 4) and a relatively shorter incisive (palatal) foramina length which ends in front of or equal to the anterior root of the first molar (M1) (Figure 3) compared to the small, and poorly defined SSF and the longer incisive foramina length which ends between the anterior root of the first molar and the t1 or t2 cusp of M1 in H. denniae. (Carleton & Stanley, 2005)It can be differentiated from H. arcimontensis in that it is generally larger in both external and cranial measurements, especially observed in the total and tail lengths, the more robust molars (Figure 5a), wider interorbital region (Figure 6a), longer length of the skull (Figure 6b), longer and broader rostrum (Figure 6c), and larger auditory bullae (Figure 5b).  For example, the mean total and tail lengths of H. arcimontensis from Mt. Rungwe is 217 and 127 mm, compared to H. anselli from the Mbizi Mountains is 246 and 146 mm. (Carleton & Stanley, 2005)Commonly confused with P. jacksoni, H. anselli has light colored soles of the hindfeet (Figure 7a), a very small tuft of hairs on the tip of the tail (Figure 7b) and a shorter snout, compared to these same features on P. jacksoni. (Carleton & Stanley, 2005)
Figure 4. Well defined subsquamosal fenestra in the otic region in H. anselli (FMNH 171360), left; and poorly defined SSF in H. denniae (FMNH 144614), right. Photograph by R. Banasiak.Figure 5. a. Upper left molars of H. anselli (FMNH 171345), top, and H. arcimontensis (FMNH 177701), bottom; b. Auditory bullae of H. anselli (FMNH 171345), top, and H. arcimontensis (FMNH 177701), bottom. Photograph by R. Banasiak.Figure 6. Dorsal view of the width of the interorbital region (a), length of skulls (b), and rostrum length (c) in H. anselli (FMNH 171345), left, and H. arcimontensis (FMNH 177701), right. Photograph by R. Banasiak.Figure 7. a. Ventral view of left hindfoot of H. anselli (FMNH 171347), left, and P. jacksoni (FMNH 178007), right; b. Tip of tail of H. anselli (FMNH 171356), left, and P. jacksoni (FMNH 178007), right. Photograph by R. Banasiak.Distribution:Hylomyscus anselli occurs in more southern African mountains from the central Angolan highlands through the disconnnected mountain chains  in northern Zambia to western most Tanzania (Ufipa Plateau) from a known altitudinal range of 1220-2300 m. (Carleton & Stanley, 2005) (Carleton et al., 2006)
Figure 8. Ecological Notes:The geographic range of Hylomyscus anselli needs more refinement. (Carleton & Stanley, 2005) 
Key Reference:1. Bishop, I. R. 1979. Notes on Praomys (Hylomyscus) in eastern Africa. Mammalia, 43:521-530.2. Carleton, M. D., J. C. Kerbis Peterhans, and W. T. Stanley. 2006. Review of the Hylomyscus denniae group (Rodentia: Muridae) in eastern Africa, with comments on the generic allocation of Epimys endorobae Heller. Proceedings of the Biological Society of Washington, 119(2):293-325.3. Carleton, M. D. and W. T. Stanley. 2005. Review of the Hylomyscus denniae complex (Rodentia: Muridae) in Tanzania, with a description of a new species. Proceedings of the Biological Society of Washington, 118(3):619-646.4. Kingdon, J. 1997. The Kingdon field guide to African mammals, AP Natural World Academic Press, Harcourt Brace & Company, San Diego, p. 206-207.5. Nowak, R. M. 1999. Walker's Mammals of the World. Sixth ed. Johns Hopkins University Press, Baltimore, 2:1344-1346, 1579.

Hylomyscus anselli

Ansell's Hylomyscus

Dorsal view of the width of the interorbital region (a), length of skulls (b), and rostrum length (c) in H. anselli (FMNH 171345), left, and H. arcimontensis (FMNH 177701), right. Photograph by R. Banasiak.Figure 7. a. Ventral view of left hindfoot of H. anselli (FMNH 171347), left, and P. jacksoni (FMNH 178007), right; b. Tip of tail of H. anselli (FMNH 171356), left, and P. jacksoni (FMNH 178007), right. Photograph by R. Banasiak.Distribution:Hylomyscus anselli occurs in more southern African mountains from the central Angolan highlands through the disconnnected mountain chains in northern Zambia to western most Tanzania (Ufipa Plateau) from a known altitudinal range of 1220-2300 m. Figure 8. Ecological Notes:The geographic range of Hylomyscus anselli needs more refinement. (Carleton & Stanley, 2005)

descrip_text_raw:
Order: Rodentia > Family: Muridae > Genus: Hylomyscus > Species: arcimontensis
Hylomyscus arcimontensis
Carleton and Stanley, 2005
Eastern Montane Hylomyscus
Figure 1. Photograph by B. Stanley.Figure 2. FMNH 177699. Photograph by R. Banasiak.
Type-Desc:
Carleton, M. D. and W. T. Stanley. 2005. Review of the Hylomyscus denniae complex (Rodentia: Muridae) in Tanzania, with a description of a new species. Proceedings of the Biological Society of Washington, 118(3):619-646.
Type Locality:
Tanzania, Tanga Region, Muheza District, East Usambara Mountains, 4.5 km WNW Amani, Monga Tea Estate, control site; elevation 900 m; geographic coordinates, as recorded by the collector, 05°06'S, 38°36'E.
Measurements:Total length: 118-262 mmHead and body: 71-120 mmTail length: 100-172 mmHindfoot length: 19.5-22 mmEar length: 8-21 mmWeight: 8-42 gDescription:The Eastern Montane Hylomyscus is blackish brown around eyes and rostrum, dark brown on the back with more vivid sides, and whitish gray on the ventrum.  The contrast between the sides and ventrum is prominent (Figure 1). (Carleton & Stanley, 2005)The tail is longer then the head and body (roughly 145% of the head and body, Figure 3a), with a very fine tuft of hairs at the tip (one has to look closely to see this, Figure 3b). (Carleton & Stanley, 2005)The hindfeet are short and narrow and pale brown on top; the fifth digit (V) is almost as long as the middle three digits (II-IV) (Figure 3c). (Carleton & Stanley, 2005)There are a total of 6 mammae in females; two inguinal and one pectoral pair. (Carleton & Stanley, 2005)The skull has a shortened rostrum (Figure 4a), thin zygomatic plate (Figure 4b) and the t3 cusp on the first upper molar is nearly indistict (Figure 5). (Carleton & Stanley, 2005) Abbreviations:  fr, frontal; max, maxillary; nas, nasal; nc, nasolacrimal capsule; pre, premaxillary; zn, zygomatic notch; zp, zygomatic plate.
Figure 3. a. Dorsal view of H. arcimontensis (FMNH 177699), showing the tail is longer then the HB; b. Fine tuft of hairs on tip of tail; c. Digit V of hindfoot is nearly as long as II-IV. Photograph by R. Banasiak.Figure 4. Lateral (a) and dorsal (b) views of the rostrum and anterior zygomatic arch in H. arcimontensis (FMNH 205178, top) and P. delectorum (FMNH 151303, bottom) Photograph by R. Banasiak.Figure 5. The presence of the t3 cusp on the first upper left molar in H. arcimontensis (FMNH 205178), poorly defined, H. denniae (FMNH 144449), nearly indistinct, and P. delectorum (FMNH 208590), well-defined. Photograph by R. Banasiak.Comparisons: The Eastern Montane Hylomyscus can be differentiated from the Montane Hylomycus (Hylomyscus denniae) by the presence of 6 mammae instead of 8, a much larger subsquamosal fenestra in the otic region, and a relatively shorter incisive foramina.  It can be differentiated from Ansell's Hylomyscus (H. anselli) in that it is generally smaller than H. anselli in both external and cranial measurements.  For example, the mean total and tail lengths of H. anselli from the Mbizi Mountains is 246 and 146 mm, compared to 217 and 127 mm for H. arcimontensis from Mt. Rungwe. (Carleton & Stanley, 2005)Within the areas where it occurs (Eastern Arc Mountains and Mt. Rungwe) the Eastern Montane Hylomyscus is most commonly confused with the East African Praomys (Praomys delectorum).  Hylomyscus has shorter broader hind feet with the fifth digit almost as long as the next three digits (Figure 3c), a fine tuft of hairs at the tip of the tail (Figure 3b), a shorter rostrum relative to the length of the skull (Figure 4a), and the females have 6 mammae instead of 8, as seen on Praomys. (Carleton & Stanley, 2005)The nasal bones of the skull do not extend as far past the incisors as in Praomys (Figure 4a), the zygomatic plate is not as wide (Figure 4b), and there is a hole at the base of the humerus that is not found in Praomys (Figure 6). The t3 cusp on the first upper molar is small and poorly defined compared to H. denniae which is virtually indistict (yet not absent) and P. deletorum which is well-defined (Figure 5). (Carleton & Stanley, 2005)Figure 6. Presence of a hole (entepicondylar foramen) at the base of the humerus in H. arcimontensis (FMNH 177702), top, which is not found in P. delectorum (FMNH 147314), bottom. Photograph by R. Banasiak.Distribution:Hylomyscus arcimontensis is found in the forested highlands from the Misuku Mountains, northern Malawi to Mount Rungwe and contiguous highlands, in southwestern Tanzania and eastwards through the Eastern Arc Mountain chain to the South Pare Mountains, northeastern Tanzania with a known altitudinal range, 900-2410 m. (Carleton & Stanley, 2005)
Figure 7. Ecological Notes:Arboreal in nature, this mouse has been found climbing shrubs, vines and small limbs.  However, the Eastern Montane Hylomyscus has also been observed on the ground in the same areas as other mice in the moist forests where it lives.  These other species include Praomys delectorum, Lophuromys aquilus, Grammomys ibeanus, and Beamys hindei.  Within the group of rodents found in the Eastern Arc and southern highlands, the Eastern Montane Hylomyscus is the most abundant arboreal rodent.  Surveys of the mountains of Tanzania conducted in July-September have revealed that roughly 20% of the female Hylomyscus captured were pregnant.  (Carleton & Stanley, 2005)Key Reference:1. Carleton, M. D. and W. T. Stanley. 2005. Review of the Hylomyscus denniae complex (Rodentia: Muridae) in Tanzania, with a description of a new species. Proceedings of the Biological Society of Washington, 118(3):619-646.2. Kingdon, J. 1997. The Kingdon field guide to African mammals, AP Natural World Academic Press, Harcourt Brace & Company, San Diego, p. 206-207.3. Nowak, R. M. 1999. Walker's Mammals of the World. Sixth ed. Johns Hopkins University Press, Baltimore, 2:1344-1346, 1579.
Description:
Order: Rodentia > Family: Muridae > Genus: Hylomyscus > Species: arcimontensis
Hylomyscus arcimontensis
Carleton and Stanley, 2005
Eastern Montane Hylomyscus
Figure 1. Photograph by B. Stanley.Figure 2. FMNH 177699. Photograph by R. Banasiak.
Type-Desc:
Carleton, M. D. and W. T. Stanley. 2005. Review of the Hylomyscus denniae complex (Rodentia: Muridae) in Tanzania, with a description of a new species. Proceedings of the Biological Society of Washington, 118(3):619-646.
Type Locality:
Tanzania, Tanga Region, Muheza District, East Usambara Mountains, 4.5 km WNW Amani, Monga Tea Estate, control site; elevation 900 m; geographic coordinates, as recorded by the collector, 05°06'S, 38°36'E.
Measurements:Total length: 118-262 mmHead and body: 71-120 mmTail length: 100-172 mmHindfoot length: 19.5-22 mmEar length: 8-21 mmWeight: 8-42 gDescription:The Eastern Montane Hylomyscus is blackish brown around eyes and rostrum, dark brown on the back with more vivid sides, and whitish gray on the ventrum. The contrast between the sides and ventrum is prominent (Figure 1). (Carleton & Stanley, 2005)The tail is longer then the head and body (roughly 145% of the head and body, Figure 3a), with a very fine tuft of hairs at the tip (one has to look closely to see this, Figure 3b). (Carleton & Stanley, 2005)The hindfeet are short and narrow and pale brown on top; the fifth digit (V) is almost as long as the middle three digits (II-IV) (Figure 3c). (Carleton & Stanley, 2005)There are a total of 6 mammae in females; two inguinal and one pectoral pair. (Carleton & Stanley, 2005)The skull has a shortened rostrum (Figure 4a), thin zygomatic plate (Figure 4b) and the t3 cusp on the first upper molar is nearly indistict (Figure 5). (Carleton & Stanley, 2005) Abbreviations: fr, frontal; max, maxillary; nas, nasal; nc, nasolacrimal capsule; pre, premaxillary; zn, zygomatic notch; zp, zygomatic plate.
Figure 3. a. Dorsal view of H. arcimontensis (FMNH 177699), showing the tail is longer then the HB; b. Fine tuft of hairs on tip of tail; c. Digit V of hindfoot is nearly as long as II-IV. Photograph by R. Banasiak.Figure 4. Lateral (a) and dorsal (b) views of the rostrum and anterior zygomatic arch in H. arcimontensis (FMNH 205178, top) and P. delectorum (FMNH 151303, bottom) Photograph by R. Banasiak.Figure 5. The presence of the t3 cusp on the first upper left molar in H. arcimontensis (FMNH 205178), poorly defined, H. denniae (FMNH 144449), nearly indistinct, and P. delectorum (FMNH 208590), well-defined. Photograph by R. Banasiak.Comparisons: The Eastern Montane Hylomyscus can be differentiated from the Montane Hylomycus (Hylomyscus denniae) by the presence of 6 mammae instead of 8, a much larger subsquamosal fenestra in the otic region, and a relatively shorter incisive foramina. It can be differentiated from Ansell's Hylomyscus (H. anselli) in that it is generally smaller than H. anselli in both external and cranial measurements. For example, the mean total and tail lengths of H. anselli from the Mbizi Mountains is 246 and 146 mm, compared to 217 and 127 mm for H. arcimontensis from Mt. Rungwe. (Carleton & Stanley, 2005)Within the areas where it occurs (Eastern Arc Mountains and Mt. Rungwe) the Eastern Montane Hylomyscus is most commonly confused with the East African Praomys (Praomys delectorum). Hylomyscus has shorter broader hind feet with the fifth digit almost as long as the next three digits (Figure 3c), a fine tuft of hairs at the tip of the tail (Figure 3b), a shorter rostrum relative to the length of the skull (Figure 4a), and the females have 6 mammae instead of 8, as seen on Praomys. (Carleton & Stanley, 2005)The nasal bones of the skull do not extend as far past the incisors as in Praomys (Figure 4a), the zygomatic plate is not as wide (Figure 4b), and there is a hole at the base of the humerus that is not found in Praomys (Figure 6). The t3 cusp on the first upper molar is small and poorly defined compared to H. denniae which is virtually indistict (yet not absent) and P. deletorum which is well-defined (Figure 5). (Carleton & Stanley, 2005)Figure 6. Presence of a hole (entepicondylar foramen) at the base of the humerus in H. arcimontensis (FMNH 177702), top, which is not found in P. delectorum (FMNH 147314), bottom. Photograph by R. Banasiak.Distribution:Hylomyscus arcimontensis is found in the forested highlands from the Misuku Mountains, northern Malawi to Mount Rungwe and contiguous highlands, in southwestern Tanzania and eastwards through the Eastern Arc Mountain chain to the South Pare Mountains, northeastern Tanzania with a known altitudinal range, 900-2410 m. (Carleton & Stanley, 2005)
Figure 7. Ecological Notes:Arboreal in nature, this mouse has been found climbing shrubs, vines and small limbs. However, the Eastern Montane Hylomyscus has also been observed on the ground in the same areas as other mice in the moist forests where it lives. These other species include Praomys delectorum, Lophuromys aquilus, Grammomys ibeanus, and Beamys hindei. Within the group of rodents found in the Eastern Arc and southern highlands, the Eastern Montane Hylomyscus is the most abundant arboreal rodent. Surveys of the mountains of Tanzania conducted in July-September have revealed that roughly 20% of the female Hylomyscus captured were pregnant. (Carleton & Stanley, 2005)Key Reference:1. Carleton, M. D. and W. T. Stanley. 2005. Review of the Hylomyscus denniae complex (Rodentia: Muridae) in Tanzania, with a description of a new species. Proceedings of the Biological Society of Washington, 118(3):619-646.2. Kingdon, J. 1997. The Kingdon field guide to African mammals, AP Natural World Academic Press, Harcourt Brace & Company, San Diego, p. 206-207.3. Nowak, R. M. 1999. Walker's Mammals of the World. Sixth ed. Johns Hopkins University Press, Baltimore, 2:1344-1346, 1579.

descrip_text_raw:
Order: Rodentia > Family: Muridae > Genus: Hylomyscus > Species: denniae
Hylomyscus denniae
(Thomas, 1906)
Montane Hylomyscus
Figure 1. FMNH 144449. Photograph by R. Banasiak.Figure 2. FMNH 144614. Photograph by R. Banasiak.
Type-Desc:
Thomas, O. 1906. Descriptions of new mammals from Mount Ruwenzori. Annals and Magazine of Natural History, ser. 7, 18:136-147.
Type Locality:
Uganda, Mubuku Valley, Ruwenzori East, 7000 ft (2134 m).
Measurements:Head and body: 71-120 mmTail length: 100-172 mmHindfoot length: 19.5-22 mmWeight: 8-42 gDescription:The Montane Hylomyscus (Hylomyscus denniae) has a soft and woolly, buffy fawn colour to the dorsal pelage with a whitish to buff colour on the ventral side. The head is greyer than the dorsal back side with the lower muzzle parts as white (Figure 1).  (Bishop, 1979; Thomas, 1906)Hylomyscus denniae are good climbers and a common resident of the montane forests of east central Tanzania.  It is commonly confused with Praomys, but has light colored soles (ventral side) of the hindfeet (Figure 3a), a very small tuft of hairs on the tip of the tail (Figure 3b), a shorter snout (Figure 4a), and the t3 cusp on the first upper molar is nearly indistict from the t2 cusp (Figure 5). (Carleton et al., 2006) Abbreviations:  fr, frontal; if, incisive foramina; max, maxillary; nas, nasal; nc, nasolacrimal capsule; pal, palate; pre, premaxillary; zn, zygomatic notch; zp, zygomatic plate.
Figure 3. a. Ventral view of left hindfoot of H. denniae (FMNH 144466), left, and P. delectorum (FMNH 192740), right; b. Tip of tail of H. denniae (FMNH 144466), left, and P. delectorum (FMNH 192740), right. Photograph by R. Banasiak.Figure 4. Lateral (a) and dorsal (b) views of the rostrum and anterior zygomatic arch in H. denniae (FMNH 144611, top) and P. delectorum (FMNH 151303, bottom) Photograph by R. Banasiak.Figure 5. The presence of the t3 cusp on the first upper left molar in H. denniae (FMNH 144449), nearly indistinct, H. arcimontensis (FMNH 205178), poorly defined, and P. delectorum (FMNH 208590), well-defined. Photograph by R. Banasiak.Comparisons: The skull of H. denniae has a long incisive (palatal) foramina compared to H. stella (Figure 6). (Bishop, 1979) For example, in the holotype for H. denniae, the skull length is 27 mm, the incisive (palatal) foramina length is 6.4 mm, and the ratio between these two lengths is 0.237 as compared to the measurments in the holotype for H. stella, 24.8 mm, 5.1 mm, and 0.205, respectively. (Bishop, 1979; Thomas, 1906, 1911) Hylomyscus denniae can be differentiated from H. arcimontensis or H. anselli by the presence of 8 mammary glands instead of 6. (Carleton & Stanley, 2005; Carleton et al., 2006)Usually confused with Praomys delectorum, Hylomyscus denniae can be differentiated from it by looking at several components of the skull. The rostrum in H. denniae is short and truncated and the nasal bone of the skull does not extend as far past the incisors as in Praomys (Figure 4a). The dorsal view of the zygomatic arch and rostrum shows that the zygomatic notch of H. denniae is shallow where as in P. delectorum the notch is deep and conspicuous (Figure 4b). The t3 cusp on the first upper molar is very small and weakly defined (virtually indistict), from the t2 cusp, compared to H. arcimontensis which is small and poorly defined and P. deletorum which is well-defined (Figure 5). (Carleton et al., 2006)In the hindfoot of  Hylomycus, the metatarsal and phalangeal proportions are relatively short and broad, unlike the proportions for Praomys which are long and narrow.  Digit V in Hylomycus is long with the claw reaching almost to the end of the third or ungual phalanx of digits II-IV compared to digit V in Praomys which is much shorter relative to digits II-IV, only extending to the middle of the second phalanx (Figure 7a). A significant difference between these two species is the pocession of an entepicondylar foramen in Hylomyscus denniae, a structure which Praomys delectorum is lacking (Figure 7b). (Carleton et al., 2006)
Figure 6. Incisvie (palatal) foramina of H. denniae (FMNH 144614), left, longer length just past first molar; and H. stella (FMNH 160553), right, shorter length just above first molar. Photograph by R. Banasiak.Figure 7. a. Dorsal view of the left HF of H. denniae (FMNH 144587), left, P. delectorum (FMNH 151303), right; b. The left humerus of  H. denniae (FMNH 144626), left, and P. delectorum (FMNH 147314), right. Photograph by R. Banasiak.Distribution:Centered in the eastern African mountains, Hylomyscus denniae ranges from the northern sections of the Albertine Rift in northeastern Democratic Republic of Congo and the central East African mountains of Uganda, Kenya and Tanzania. (Carlton & Stanley, 2005) A higher elevational species, H. denniae is also found in forest islands in the Afro-alpine and subalpine moorlands from west central to Angola, Uganda, western Rwanda, and Kenya down through Tanzania and Zambia. (Kingdon, 1984, 1997) (Wilson and Reeder, 2005)
Figure 8. Ecological Notes:As one of the species focused on in recent small mammal surveys, Hylomyscus denniaehas a patchy and scattered local distribution throughout portions of the Eastern Arc Mountains. (Carlton & Stanley, 2005)
Key Reference:1. Bishop, I. R. 1979. Notes on Praomys (Hylomyscus) in eastern Africa. Mammalia, 43:521-530.2. Carleton, M. D. and W. T. Stanley. 2005. Review of the Hylomyscus denniae complex (Rodentia: Muridae) in Tanzania, with a description of a new species. Proceedings of the Biological Society of Washington, 118(3):619-646.3. Carleton, M. D., J. C. Kerbis Peterhans, and W. T. Stanley. 2006. Review of the Hylomyscus denniae group (Rodentia: Muridae) in eastern Africa, with comments on the generic allocation of Epimys endorobae Heller. Proceedings of the Biological Society of Washington, 119(2):293-325.4. Kingdon, J. 1984. East African mammals: An atlas of evolution in Africa. (Hares and Rodents). University of Chicago Press, Chicago, 2B:585, 593.5. Kingdon, J. 1997. The Kingdon field guide to African mammals, AP Natural World Academic Press, Harcourt Brace & Company, San Diego, p. 206.6. Nowak, R. M. 1999. Walker's Mammals of the World. Sixth ed. Johns Hopkins University Press, Baltimore, 2:1344-1346, 1579.7. Thomas,O. 1906. Descriptions of new mammals from Mount Ruwenzori. Annals and Magazine of Natural History, ser. 7, 18:136-147.8. Thomas,O. 1911. Thre new African rodents. Annals and Magazine of Natural History, ser. 8, 7:590-593. 9. Wilson, D. E., and D. M. Reeder (eds.). 2005. Mammal species of the world, a taxonomic and geographic reference, Third ed. The Johns Hopkins University Press, Baltimore, 2:1336.

descrip_text_raw:
Order: Rodentia > Family: Muridae > Genus: Hylomyscus > Species: stella
Hylomyscus stella
(Thomas, 1911)
Stella Hylomyscus
Figure 1. Photograph by B. Stanley.Figure 2. FMNH 192978. Photograph by R. Banasiak.
Type-Desc:
Thomas, O. 1911. Thre new African rodents. Annals and Magazine of Natural History, ser. 8, 7:590-593.
Type Locality:
E Dem. Rep. Congo, Ituri Forest, between Mawambi and Avakubi.
Measurements:Total length: 176-261 mmHead and body: 79-104 mmTail length: 111-150 mmHindfoot length: 16-20 mmEar length: 16-20 mmWeight: 15-24 gDescription:The dorsal pellage of the Stella Wood Mouse (Hylomyscus stella) is a dull rufous fawn or redish-brown with the base of the hairs a dark grey colour and a whitish-grey ventral underside , the bas of the hairs grey with greyish white tips (Figure 1), but animals with darker and more greyish fur may occur, which usually indicates that the specimen is either young and the pellage has not fully developed the redish-brown colour or that the specimen is older and in moult or the fur has become rubbed, losing its colour. (Thomas, 1911; Rosevear, 1969) The underside or soles of the feet are a dullish white or brownish colour. (Thomas, 1911; Rosevear, 1969)Hylomyscus stella are good climbers and a common resident of the montane forests of east central Tanzania.  Commonly confused with Praomys delectorum,  H. stella is differentiated from it by its light colored soles of the hindfeet (Figure 3a) and a very small tuft of hairs on the tip of the tail (Figure 3b) unlike the darker soles of P. delectorum and the lack of hairs on the tip of the tail.  Abbreviations: fr, frontal; if, incisive foramina; max, maxillary; nas, nasal; nc, nasolacrimal capsule; pal, palate; pre, premaxillary; zn, zygomatic notch; zp, zygomatic plate.
Figure 3. a. Ventral view of left hindfoot of H. stella (FMNH 192992), left, and P. delectorum (FMNH 192740), right; b. Tip of tail of H. stella (FMNH 192992), left, and P. delectorum (FMNH 192740), right. Photograph by R. Banasiak.Comparisons: The skull of H. stella has a shorter incisive (palatal) foramina compared to H. denniae (Figure 4). (Bishop, 1979) For example, in the holotype for H. stella, the skull length is 24.8 mm, the incisive (palatal) foramina length is 5.1 mm, and the ratio between these two lengths is 0.205 as compared to the measurments in the holotype for H. denniae, 27 mm, 6.4 mm, and 0.237, respectively. (Bishop, 1979; Thomas, 1906, 1911)Hylomyscus stella can be differentiated from Praomys delectorum by examining the skulls of the two species. In H. stella, the rostrum is truncated with the nasal bone not extending as far past the incisors as in Praomys (Figure 5a). In the dorsal view, the zygomatic notch of H. stella is shallow where as in P. delectorum the notch is deep and conspicuous (Figure 5b). (Carleton et al., 2006)A significant difference between these two species is the pocession of an entepicondylar foramen in Hylomyscus stella, a structure which Praomys delectorum is lacking (Figure 6). (Carleton et al., 2006)Figure 4. Incisvie (palatal) foramina of H. stella (FMNH 160553), left, shorter length; and H. denniae (FMNH 144614), right, longer length. Photograph by R. Banasiak.Figure 5. Lateral (a) and dorsal (b) views of the rostrum and anterior zygomatic arch in H. stella (FMNH 160553, top) and P. delectorum (FMNH 151303, bottom) Photograph by R. Banasiak.Figure 6. Presence of a hole (entepicondylar foramen) at the base of the humerus in H. stella (FMNH 192978), top, which is not found in P. delectorum (FMNH 147314), bottom. Photograph by R. Banasiak.Distribution:Distributed throughout central and eastern Africa from Nigeria south to northern Angola, east to Kenya, Uganda, and east-central Tanzania but species distribution limits are unknown. (Wilson and Reeder, 2005) Hylomyscua stella is considered a rain forest species and will be found throughout the lower altitudinal forests of East Africa. (Kingdon, 1984)
Figure 7. Key Reference:1. Bishop, I. R. 1979. Notes on Praomys (Hylomyscus) in eastern Africa. Mammalia, 43:521-530.2. Carleton, M. D., J. C. Kerbis Peterhans, and W. T. Stanley. 2006. Review of the Hylomyscus denniae group (Rodentia: Muridae) in eastern Africa, with comments on the generic allocation of Epimys endorobae Heller. Proceedings of the Biological Society of Washington, 119(2):293-325.3. Kingdon, J. 1984. East African mammals: An atlas of evolution in Africa. (Hares and Rodents). University of Chicago Press, Chicago, 2B:585, 592-594.4. Kingdon, J. 1997. Johns Hopkins University Press, Baltimore, 2:1344-1346, 1579.6. Rosevear, D. R. 1969. The rodents of West Africa. Trustees of the British Museum (Natural History), London, 677:453.7. Thomas,O. 1906. Descriptions of new mammals from Mount Ruwenzori. Annals and Magazine of Natural History, ser. 7, 18:136-147.8. Thomas,O. 1911. Thre new African rodents. The Johns Hopkins University Press, Baltimore, 2:1336.
Description:
Order: Rodentia > Family: Muridae > Genus: Hylomyscus > Species: stella
Hylomyscus stella
(Thomas, 1911)
Stella Hylomyscus
Figure 1. Photograph by B. Stanley.Figure 2. FMNH 192978. Photograph by R. Banasiak.
Type-Desc:
Thomas, O. 1911. Thre new African rodents. Annals and Magazine of Natural History, ser. 8, 7:590-593.
Type Locality:
E Dem. Rep. Congo, Ituri Forest, between Mawambi and Avakubi.
Measurements:Total length: 176-261 mmHead and body: 79-104 mmTail length: 111-150 mmHindfoot length: 16-20 mmEar length: 16-20 mmWeight: 15-24 gDescription:The dorsal pellage of the Stella Wood Mouse (Hylomyscus stella) is a dull rufous fawn or redish-brown with the base of the hairs a dark grey colour and a whitish-grey ventral underside , the bas of the hairs grey with greyish white tips (Figure 1), but animals with darker and more greyish fur may occur, which usually indicates that the specimen is either young and the pellage has not fully developed the redish-brown colour or that the specimen is older and in moult or the fur has become rubbed, losing its colour. (Thomas, 1911; Rosevear, 1969) The underside or soles of the feet are a dullish white or brownish colour. (Thomas, 1911; Rosevear, 1969)Hylomyscus stella are good climbers and a common resident of the montane forests of east central Tanzania. Commonly confused with Praomys delectorum, H. stella is differentiated from it by its light colored soles of the hindfeet (Figure 3a) and a very small tuft of hairs on the tip of the tail (Figure 3b) unlike the darker soles of P. delectorum and the lack of hairs on the tip of the tail. Abbreviations: fr, frontal; if, incisive foramina; max, maxillary; nas, nasal; nc, nasolacrimal capsule; pal, palate; pre, premaxillary; zn, zygomatic notch; zp, zygomatic plate.
Figure 3. a. Ventral view of left hindfoot of H. stella (FMNH 192992), left, and P. delectorum (FMNH 192740), right; b. Tip of tail of H. stella (FMNH 192992), left, and P. delectorum (FMNH 192740), right. Photograph by R. Banasiak.Comparisons: The skull of H. stella has a shorter incisive (palatal) foramina compared to H. denniae (Figure 4). (Bishop, 1979) For example, in the holotype for H. stella, the skull length is 24.8 mm, the incisive (palatal) foramina length is 5.1 mm, and the ratio between these two lengths is 0.205 as compared to the measurments in the holotype for H. denniae, 27 mm, 6.4 mm, and 0.237, respectively. (Bishop, 1979; Thomas, 1906, 1911)Hylomyscus stella can be differentiated from Praomys delectorum by examining the skulls of the two species. In H. stella, the rostrum is truncated with the nasal bone not extending as far past the incisors as in Praomys (Figure 5a). In the dorsal view, the zygomatic notch of H. stella is shallow where as in P. delectorum the notch is deep and conspicuous (Figure 5b). (Carleton et al., 2006)A significant difference between these two species is the pocession of an entepicondylar foramen in Hylomyscus stella, a structure which Praomys delectorum is lacking (Figure 6). (Carleton et al., 2006)Figure 4. Incisvie (palatal) foramina of H. stella (FMNH 160553), left, shorter length; and H. denniae (FMNH 144614), right, longer length. Photograph by R. Banasiak.Figure 5. Lateral (a) and dorsal (b) views of the rostrum and anterior zygomatic arch in H. stella (FMNH 160553, top) and P. delectorum (FMNH 151303, bottom) Photograph by R. Banasiak.Figure 6. Presence of a hole (entepicondylar foramen) at the base of the humerus in H. stella (FMNH 192978), top, which is not found in P. delectorum (FMNH 147314), bottom. Photograph by R. Banasiak.Distribution:Distributed throughout central and eastern Africa from Nigeria south to northern Angola, east to Kenya, Uganda, and east-central Tanzania but species distribution limits are unknown. (Wilson and Reeder, 2005) Hylomyscua stella is considered a rain forest species and will be found throughout the lower altitudinal forests of East Africa. (Kingdon, 1984)

descrip_text_raw:
Order: Rodentia > Family: Muridae > Genus: Lemniscomys > Species: rosalia
Lemniscomys rosalia
(Thomas, 1904)
Single-striped Lemniscomys
Figure 1. Photograph by B. Stanley.Figure 2. FMNH 158039. Photograph by R. Banasiak.
Type-Desc:
Ann. Mag. Nat. Hist., ser. 7, 13:414.
Type Locality:
Tanzania, Nguru Mtns, Monda.
Measurements:Total length: 122-260 mmHead and body: 98-140 mmTail length: 102-155 mmHindfoot length: 23-32 mmEar length: 11-18 mmWeight: 20-68 gDescription:This rodent has a prominent black stripe down the midline of the back, a bicoloured tail and a white belly.  The upper incisors are not grooved.
Comparisons: Other Lemniscomys have more than one line along the back.  Other rodents with one line have either grooved upper incisors (Pelomys), or are smaller with a tail that is much longer than the head and body and only three toes on the front foot (Dendromus), or the belly is a dirty gray colour and not white (Arvicanthis).
Distribution:Lemniscomys rosalia is distributed throughout south and east Africa from the Dem. Rep. of Congo to southern Kenya down to northern Namibia, Botswana and northern South Africa. This species is found in grasslands and woodland localities. (Kingdon, 1984, 1997) L. rosalia has been recorded in variety of localities within Tanzania, including Tarangire National Park and near Dar es Salaam.
Figure 3. Key Reference:1. Kingdon, J. 1984. East African mammals: An atlas of evolution in Africa. (Hares and Rodents). University of Chicago Press, Chicago, 2B:617-622.2. Kingdon, J. 1997. The Kingdon field guide to African mammals, AP Natural World Academic Press, Harcourt Brace & Company, San Diego, p. 212-213.3. Nowak, R. M. 1999. Walker's Mammals of the World. Sixth ed. Johns Hopkins University Press, Baltimore, 2:1344-1346, 1596-1597.4. Swynnerton, G. H., and R. W. Hayman. 1951. A checklist of the land mammals of the Tanganyika Territory and the Zanzibar Protectorate. Journal of the East African Natural History Society, 20(6):274-392.

descrip_text_raw:
Order: Rodentia > Family: Muridae > Genus: Lemniscomys > Species: striatus
Lemniscomys striatus
(Linnaeus, 1758)
Typical Lemniscomys
Figure 1. Photograph by B. Stanley.Figure 2. FMNH 171369. Photograph by R. Banasiak.
Type-Desc:
Syst. Nat., 10th ed., 1:62.
Type Locality:
'India' (= Sierra Leone; G. M. Allen, 1939:394).
Measurements:Head and body: 98-140 mmTail length: 102-155 mmHindfoot length: 23-32 mmWeight: 20-68 gDescription:This rodent has several prominent black stripes down the midline of the back, that are interrupted with spots, a bicoloured tail and a white belly.  
Comparisons: The only other rodents with several black stripes down the back are Lemniscomys zebra (where the stripes are not interrupted with spots) or Rhabdomys (where there are only four stripes; L. striatus has more than four stripes).  
Distribution:Lemniscomys striatus has been recorded in variety of grassland and savanna habitats.
Figure 3. Key Reference:1. Kingdon, J. 1984. East African mammals: An atlas of evolution in Africa. (Hares and Rodents). University of Chicago Press, Chicago, 2B:617-622.2. Kingdon, J. 1997. The Kingdon field guide to African mammals, AP Natural World Academic Press, Harcourt Brace & Company, San Diego, p. 212-213.3. Nowak, R. M. 1999. Walker's Mammals of the World. Sixth ed. Johns Hopkins University Press, Baltimore, 2:1344-1346, 1596-1597.4. Swynnerton, G. H., and R. W. Hayman. 1951. A checklist of the land mammals of the Tanganyika Territory and the Zanzibar Protectorate. Journal of the East African Natural History Society, 20(6):274-392.

descrip_text_raw:
Order: Rodentia > Family: Muridae > Genus: Lemniscomys > Species: zebra
Lemniscomys zebra
(Heuglin, 1864)
Heuglin's Lemniscomys
Figure 1. Photograph by B. Stanley.Figure 2. FMNH 17204. Photograph by R. Banasiak.
Type-Desc:
Beit. Zool. Cent.-Afrika's Leopoldina, 31:10.
Type Locality:
Sudan, Bahr el Ghazal (Carleton and Van der Straeten, 1997, provided additional information).
Measurements:Head and body: 90-118 mmTail length: 95-133 mmHindfoot length: 22-26 mmWeight: 23-41 gDescription:This rodent has several prominent continuous black stripes down the midline of the back that are not interrupted with spots, a bicoloured tail and a white belly.  
Comparisons: The only other rodents with several black stripes down the back are Lemniscomys striatus (where the stripes are interrupted with spots) or Rhabdomys (where there are only four stripes; L. zebra has more than four stripes).  
Distribution:Lemniscomys zebra is found in the drier savannas and steppes that border the Sahara south from Senegal across the continent to the Sudan and down to Tanzania. (Kingdon, 1984, 1997) This species has been recorded in variety of dry rocky habitats within Tanzania.
Figure 3. Key Reference:1. Kingdon, J. 1984. East African mammals: An atlas of evolution in Africa. (Hares and Rodents). University of Chicago Press, Chicago, 2B:617-622.2. Kingdon, J. 1997. The Kingdon field guide to African mammals, AP Natural World Academic Press, Harcourt Brace & Company, San Diego, p. 212-213.3. Nowak, R. M. 1999. Walker's Mammals of the World. Sixth ed. Johns Hopkins University Press, Baltimore, 2:1344-1346, 1596-1597.4. Swynnerton, G. H., and R. W. Hayman. 1951. A checklist of the land mammals of the Tanganyika Territory and the Zanzibar Protectorate. Journal of the East African Natural History Society, 20(6):274-392.

Order: Rodentia > Family: Muridae > Genus: Lophuromys > Species: aquilus
Lophuromys aquilus
(True, 1892)
Dark-colored Brush-furred Rat
Figure 1. Photograph by B. Stanley.Figure 2. FMNH 163621. Photograph by R. Banasiak.
Type-Desc:
Proc. U. S. Nat. Mus., 15:460.
Type Locality:
East Africa, Tanzania, Mt Kilimanjaro, 8000 ft (2650 m; coordinates given by W. Verheyen et al., 2002).
Measurements:Total length: 162-215 mmHead and body: 100-134 mmTail length: 58-94 mmHindfoot length: 19-23 mmEar length: 16-20 mmWeight: 45-95 gDescription:These rats are recognizable because of their distinctive fur.  Often the tail is missing and they have a very strong odor.Distribution:One of the most numerous rodents in tropical Africa, Lophuromys aquilus can be found in moist scrub, forest, and grassy areas from sea-level to 3,000 m. (Kingdon, 1984, 1997)

descrip_text_raw:
Order: Rodentia > Family: Muridae > Genus: Mastomys > Species: natalensis
Mastomys natalensis
(Smith, 1834)
Natal Mastomys
Figure 1. Photograph by B. Stanley.Figure 2. FMNH 153963. Photograph by R. Banasiak.
Type-Desc:
Smith, A. 1833-1834. An epitome of African Zoology; or, a concise description of the objects of the animal Kingdom inhabiting Africa, its islands and seas. South African Quarterly Journal, 2:16-32, 49-64, 81-96, 113-128, 145-160, 169-192, 209-224, 233-248.
Type Locality:
South Africa, KwaZulu-Natal, Port Natal (= Durban).
Measurements:Total length: 81-253 mmHead and body: 90-155 mmTail length: 88-150 mmHindfoot length: 18-30 mmEar length: 9-23 mmWeight: 20-70 gDescription:Look for the incisive foramina ending in front of the first molars in the upper toothrows.  The genus gets the English name from the large number of teats in females.Distribution:Mastomys natalensis is found in savannas, woodlands, secondary growth, forest clearings, fields near villages and in houses. This species in distributed in all but the driest areas just northwest and south of the Sahara. (Kingdon, 1984, 1997)
Figure 3. Key Reference:1. Kingdon, J. 1984. East African mammals: An atlas of evolution in Africa. (Hares and Rodents). University of Chicago Press, Chicago, 2B:584, 587-589.2. Kingdon, J. 1997. Johns Hopkins University Press, Baltimore, 2:1344-1346, 1576-1577.4. Swynnerton, G. H., and R. W. Hayman. 1951. A checklist of the land mammals of the Tanganyika Territory and the Zanzibar Protectorate. Journal of the East African Natural History Society, 20(6):274-392.
Description: Look for the incisive foramina ending in front of the first molars in the upper toothrows. The genus gets the English name from the large number of teats in females.

(Kingdon, 1984, 1997)

Figure 1. Photograph by B. Stanley.Figure 2. FMNH 153343. Photograph by R. Banasiak.
